content:
The Act is titled the "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008" and includes definitions for various terms. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892) is amended to define hydrographic data as information acquired through various surveying methods and used in providing hydrographic services. Hydrographic services include the management, maintenance, interpretation, certification, and dissemination of bathymetric and hydrographic data. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 defines hydrographic data as information used in providing hydrographic services, including the management, maintenance, interpretation, certification, and dissemination of various types of data. This Act also encompasses the development of nautical information systems and related activities. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 defines hydrographic data as information used in providing services, including the development of nautical information systems and related activities. The Coast and Geodetic Survey Act refers to the functions and duties of the Coast and Geodetic Survey. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF THE ADMINISTRATOR. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892a) is amended to promote safe and efficient marine transportation by providing hydrographic services and fulfilling the purposes of the Act. The Administrator is authorized to procure, lease, evaluate, test, develop, and operate as needed. The Administrator under the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act may procure, lease, test, and operate vessels, equipment, and technologies for safe navigation and hydrographic data acquisition. They are also required to design, install, and maintain real-time hydrographic monitoring systems for navigation safety. Additionally, they may acquire hydrographic data to support coastal and ocean conservation efforts. The Administrator under the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act may acquire hydrographic data and provide services for navigation safety, conservation of coastal resources, emergency response, and homeland security needs. They may also collaborate with other agencies to establish joint centers. The Administrator under the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act may acquire hydrographic data for navigation safety, coastal resource conservation, emergency response, and homeland security needs. They can collaborate with other agencies to establish joint centers for these purposes. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to include a Hydrographic Services Review Panel consisting of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator. The panel will also have nonvoting members from the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and NOAA. Voting members must be qualified in disciplines related to hydrographic data and services, marine transportation, port administration, vessel pilotage, coastal and fishery management. Authorization of appropriations is also included. SEC. 5. Authorization of appropriations under the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended. Authorization of appropriations for nautical mapping, charting, and hydrographic surveys under the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998:
- $55,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $56,000,000 for 2010, $57,000,000 for 2011, and $58,000,000 for 2012 for mapping and charting functions.
- $32,130,000 for 2009, $32,760,000 for 2010, $33,390,000 for 2011, and $34,020,000 for 2012 for contracting hydrographic surveys.
- $25,900,000 for 2009 to operate US-owned hydrographic survey vessels. Authorization of appropriations for nautical mapping, charting, hydrographic surveys, geodetic functions, and tide/current measurements under the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998:
- Funding allocated for fiscal years 2009 to 2012 for various functions:
    - Mapping and charting: $55,000,000 for 2009, $56,000,000 for 2010, $57,000,000 for 2011, and $58,000,000 for 2012.
    - Contracting hydrographic surveys: $32,130,000 for 2009, $32,760,000 for 2010, $33,390,000 for 2011, and $34,020,000 for 2012.
    - Operating US-owned hydrographic survey vessels: $25,900,000 for 2009, $26,400,000 for 2010, $26,900,000 for 2011, and $27,400,000 for 2012.
    - Geodetic functions: $32,640,000 for 2009, $33,280,000 for 2010, $33,920,000 for 2011, and $34,560,000 for 2012.
    - Tide and current measurements: $27,000,000 for 2009. Authorization of appropriations for nautical mapping, charting, hydrographic surveys, geodetic functions, and tide/current measurements under the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 includes funding for various functions from 2009 to 2012. This funding includes amounts for mapping and charting, contracting hydrographic surveys, operating US-owned hydrographic survey vessels, geodetic functions, and acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel. SEC. 6 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Commissioned Officer Corps Act of 2002 is amended to increase the total number of authorized commissioned officers from 321 to 379, subject to certain conditions being met.
